title: 1800 followers problem
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\large \sum_{k=1}^{1800} \psi(k)"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If the above sum can be expressed as "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"aH_b-c\gamma-d"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for some not necessarily distinct positive integers "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a,b,c"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" d"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", evaluate "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a+b+c+d"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b,c"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is maximum possible."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Notations","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":":"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"bulletList","content":[{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\psi(\cdot)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" represents the "},{"type":"text","text":"digamma function","marks":[{"attrs":{"href":"","target":"_blank"},"type":"link"}]},{"type":"text","text":"."}]}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"H_n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" denotes the "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n^\text{th}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"text","text":"harmonic number","marks":[{"attrs":{"href":"","target":"_blank"},"type":"link"}]},{"type":"text","text":"."}]}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\gamma"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" represents the "},{"type":"text","text":"Euler-Mascheroni constant","marks":[{"attrs":{"href":"","target":"_blank"},"type":"link"}]},{"type":"text","text":" which is approxiamately equal to 0.5772."}]}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"heading","attrs":[{"level":6}],"content":[{"type":"text","text":"This problem is original."}]}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            It would be better if you provide proof for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\psi(z+1)=H_z-\gamma"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" . Anyways , a nice solution +1

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \psi(1+k) = \dfrac{1}{k} + \psi(k) "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \psi(1) = -\gamma "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
Using both these properties, "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \psi(1) = -\gamma "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \psi(2) = 1 -\gamma "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \psi(3) = 1 + \dfrac{1}{2} - \gamma "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"."}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
 "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"."}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"   "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \psi(1800) = 1 + \dfrac{1}{2} +  \ldots \dfrac{1}{1799} - \gamma "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
Adding all the terms, "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^{1800}\psi(k) = \dfrac{1799}{1} + \dfrac{1798}{2} + \dfrac{1797}{3} + \ldots + \dfrac{1}{1799} - 1800\gamma "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^{1800}\psi(k) = \dfrac{1800}{1} - 1 + \dfrac{1800}{2} - 1 + \dfrac{1800}{3} - 1 + \ldots + \dfrac{1800}{1799} - 1 -1800\gamma "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^{1800}\psi(k)  = 1800\left(1 + \dfrac{1}{2} + \dfrac{1}{3} + \ldots + \dfrac{1}{1799}\right) - 1799 - 1800\gamma "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^{1800}\psi(k) = 1800H_{1799} - 1799 - 1800\gamma "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
I reached this stage and input my solution as 7198 and wondered why my answer was wrong, annoyed Nihar( :P ) and got him to write the max condition. "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^{1800}\psi(k)  = 1800H_{1799} - 1799 - 1800\gamma  = 1800H_{1800} - 1800 - 1800\gamma "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"   "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"In general, "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^{n}\psi(k) = nH_{n-1} - (n-1) - n\gamma = n(H_{n} - \gamma - 1) "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"    "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The proof of the two properties I mentioned  can be found on the Brilliant Digamma wiki."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"

                                            Thank you for the solution and saving me from reports :) +1

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Claim :","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":"  "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\psi(k+1) = \psi(k) + \dfrac{1}{k}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Proof :","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" An easy proof can be found "},{"type":"text","text":"here.","marks":[{"attrs":{"href":"","target":"_blank"},"type":"link"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Now using "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\psi(1) = - \gamma"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", we get "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\psi(2) = -\gamma + 1 = -\gamma + H_{1} \cdots \cdots (*)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\psi(3) = \psi(2) + 1/2 = -\gamma + H_{2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" [Using (*)]"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\psi(4) = -\gamma  + H_{3}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\psi(5) = -\gamma  + H_{4}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Thus noticing the pattern, we get "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\psi(n+1) = -\gamma + H_{n}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Thus "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^{1800} \psi(k) = -1800 \gamma + \sum_{i=1}^{1799} H_{i}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Claim :","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\sum_{i=1}^{n} H_{i} = (n+1)H_{n+1} - (n+1)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Proof :","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" Induction will do the job. (Left as an exercise for the reader.)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Thus "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^{1800} \psi(k) = -1800 \gamma + \sum_{i=1}^{1799} H_{i} = -1800 \gamma +1800H_{1800} -1800"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Final answer = "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1800+1800+1800+1800 = 1800 \times 4 = \boxed{\boxed{7200}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 180 Follower Problem
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"What is the smallest "},{"type":"text","text":"positive integer","marks":[{"attrs":{"href":"","target":"_blank"},"type":"link"}]},{"type":"text","text":" that has precisely 180 "},{"type":"text","text":"positive divisors","marks":[{"attrs":{"href":"","target":"_blank"},"type":"link"}]},{"type":"text","text":"?"}]},{"type":"text","text":"\n\n"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Note","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":": Please include a proof that the value you found is indeed the lowest."}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                    "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Relevant wiki: Number of Factors","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Using the divisor count formula, the number "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n = p_1^{e_1} p_2^{e_2} p_3^{e_3} \ldots"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" has "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(1+e_1) (1+e_2) (1+e_3) \ldots"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" divisors. (Note that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"e_1, e_2, e_3, \ldots"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" may be zero, in which case the corresponding "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1+e_1, 1+e_2, 1+e_3, \ldots"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are 1 and thus don't contribute anything to the product.) In order to have 180 divisors, we need "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1+e_1, 1+e_2, 1+e_3, \ldots"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" to multiply to 180. If I'm not mistaken, there are 26 such ways, ignoring order and ignoring 1s:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"bulletList","content":[{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"180"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"90 \cdot 2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"60 \cdot 3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"45 \cdot 4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"45 \cdot 2 \cdot 2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"36 \cdot 5"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"30 \cdot 6"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"30 \cdot 3 \cdot 2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"20 \cdot 9"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"20 \cdot 3 \cdot 3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"18 \cdot 10"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"18 \cdot 5 \cdot 2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"15 \cdot 12"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"15 \cdot 6 \cdot 2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"15 \cdot 4 \cdot 3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"15 \cdot 3 \cdot 2 \cdot 2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"12 \cdot 5 \cdot 3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10 \cdot 9 \cdot 2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10 \cdot 6 \cdot 3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10 \cdot 3 \cdot 3 \cdot 2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"9 \cdot 5 \cdot 4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"9 \cdot 5 \cdot 2 \cdot 2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"6 \cdot 6 \cdot 5"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"6 \cdot 5 \cdot 3 \cdot 2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5 \cdot 4 \cdot 3 \cdot 3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5 \cdot 3 \cdot 3 \cdot 2 \cdot 2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(The only way I can think of to find these is by careful case-by-case analysis.)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Now, given a product "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"180 = (1+e_1) (1+e_2) (1+e_3) \ldots"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"e_1 \ge e_2 \ge e_3 \ge \ldots"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", we'd like to find "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"p_1, p_2, p_3, \ldots"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" that makes the resulting number the smallest. It's clearly better to keep "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"p_1 < p_2 < p_3 < \ldots"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". One simple way to realize this is that if for some "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"i,j"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"i < j"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", we have "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"p_i > p_j"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", then swapping them will multiply the number by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"p_i^{e_j-e_i} p_j^{e_i-e_j} = \left( \frac{p_j}{p_i} \right)^{e_i-e_j}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Because "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"e_i \ge e_j"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", the exponent is nonnegative. Because "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"p_i > p_j"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", the base is less than 1 (and positive). Thus this multiplier is not greater than 1, and so the original unswapped number cannot be the minimum; at best, it's tied for the minimum, and at worst, swapping will give a smaller result. So we can assume "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"p_i < p_j"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for all "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"i,j"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"i < j"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". In other words, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"p_1, p_2, p_3, \ldots"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are the prime numbers in that order; "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"p_1 = 2, p_2 = 3, p_3 = 5, \ldots"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Now, we can compute the minimum number given by each product. For example, take the product "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10 \cdot 3 \cdot 3 \cdot 2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1+e_1 = 10, 1+e_2 = 3, 1+e_3 = 3, 1+e_4 = 2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", or in other words, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"e_1 = 9, e_2 = 2, e_3 = 2, e_4 = 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Thus the number given by this product is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2^9 \cdot 3^2 \cdot 5^2 \cdot 7^1 = 806400"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"By computing each of the 26 possible smallest numbers, we obtain 26 candidates; simply pick the smallest. In this case, it happens with the last product: "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2^4 \cdot 3^2 \cdot 5^2 \cdot 7^1 \cdot 11^1 = \boxed{277200}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Note that we do need figuring out at least some of the products; we can't take shortcuts. For example, saying "assign the largest prime factor to the smallest base, then the next largest prime factor to the next smallest base, and so on" doesn't work, because with a product of 8, it would give "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2^1 \cdot 3^1 \cdot 5^1 = 30"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and not "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2^3 \cdot 3^1 = 24"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Even if we modify "smallest base" to "smallest base raised to its current exponent" (so that in the above case, the last 2 will get assigned to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2^2 = 4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" instead of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5^1 = 5"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"), we will still stumble for a product of 24, where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2^2 \cdot 3^1 \cdot 5^1 \cdot 7^1 = 420"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is not the optimal solution; "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2^3 \cdot 3^2 \cdot 5^1 = 360"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is. That requires us to put the factor 3 to base 3 and not base 2."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            I really liked the solution but I think there is a way to find the ways of making 180: it only has 3 prime factors so if you construct a 3 dimensional array with dimensions 3"},{"type":"text","text":"3","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":"2 (as the number is 2^2"},{"type":"text","text":"3^2","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":"5^1 and add one to each power) each element is now a factor  of 180 (i.e. the item in position (1,1,0) would have 1 factor of 2 removed, 1 factor of 3 and no factors of 5 removed) repeating this for the removed factors would give all of their factors, repeat until there are no compound numbers as the last elements of a list. Of course this is quite inefficient but it would ensure finding all factors.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}
